title: 113_s792
content: The Act titled "Explosive Materials Background Check Act" requires background checks for explosive materials. Amendments to Title 18 of the United States Code include changes to sections 841 and 842, such as adding smokeless powder and black powder substitutes to section 841 and adding a new provision in section 842 regarding court orders restraining harassment or threats towards intimate partners or their children. The amendments to Title 18 of the United States Code include a new provision in section 842 regarding court orders restraining harassment or threats towards intimate partners or their children. This provision applies to individuals who have been convicted of a misdemeanor and have a court order issued after a hearing where they had the opportunity to participate. The order must include a finding that the individual poses a credible threat to the physical safety of the partner or child, or explicitly prohibits the use of physical force that could cause bodily injury. The new provision in Title 18 of the United States Code addresses individuals convicted of misdemeanor domestic violence or those subject to court orders restraining harassment or threats towards intimate partners or their children. This provision aims to protect intimate partners from conduct that could cause bodily harm. The provision in Title 18 of the United States Code applies to individuals convicted of misdemeanor domestic violence or those subject to court orders restraining threats or violence against intimate partners or their children. In Title 18 of the United States Code, section 843 is amended to include provisions for limited permit holders to purchase specific types of powder. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code, section 843 allows for restrictions on purchasing specific types of powder by limited permit holders, particularly in cases related to terrorism or providing support for terrorism. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code, section 843 allows for restrictions on purchasing specific types of powder by limited permit holders, particularly in cases related to terrorism or providing support for terrorism. The Attorney General may withhold information relied upon for denial or revocation if it compromises national security. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code, section 843 allows for restrictions on purchasing specific types of powder by limited permit holders, particularly in cases related to terrorism or providing support for terrorism. In responding to any petition for review of a denial or revocation based on an Attorney General determination, the United States may submit summaries or redacted versions of documents to protect national security. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code, section 843 allows restrictions on purchasing specific types of powder by limited permit holders, especially in cases related to terrorism. The Attorney General may withhold information relied upon for a determination under subsection (j) if disclosure would compromise national security. The Attorney General has the discretion to deny federal explosives licenses and permits to individuals involved in terrorism or providing support for terrorism. Additionally, restrictions on purchasing certain types of powder are imposed on limited permit holders, with exceptions for smokeless powder and black powder substitutes. The Attorney General will issue guidelines for exercising authority under subsections of section 843 of title 18, United States Code, to ensure accountability and monitoring of intended goals and results. The Attorney General will issue guidelines to ensure accountability and monitoring of goals and results, including the use of terrorist watch list records in a manner that protects privacy and civil liberties.
